title: Final PPI claims made before deadline may not be settled until summer
text:
The FCA ran a publicity campaign for the August 29 PPI claim deadline using an animated likeness of Arnold Schwarzenegger

Customers who lodged a mis-selling complaint about payment protection insurance (PPI) may have to wait until next summer for a final response as banks struggle to deal with a flood of claims before the August 2019 deadline.

The City watchdog attempted to draw a line under the mis-selling scandal by setting the August 29 cut-off point.

This was accompanied by a high-profile publicity campaign, which lasted for two years and featured adverts using an animated likeness of Arnold Schwarzenegger.

Yesterday the Financial Conduct Authority (FCA) said: 'While firms have large operations in place to deal with PPI complaints, a number of them have informed us that you might not receive a final response to your complaint until summer 2020.'

Several major lenders including Lloyds, Royal Bank of Scotland and Barclays have set aside hundreds of millions of pounds extra to cover late claims.

The FCA estimates £36billion has been paid out, with a typical payout of £2,000.

In August, thinktank New City Agenda predicted that the final PPI bill would pass £50billion.
